item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign Network Test Players Killed Nearly 60,000 Nightlords
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/elden-ring-nightreign-network-test-stats

Bandai Namco has revealed some fun statistics for the recent Elden Ring Nightreign network test, in which those lucky enough to be invited got a glimpse of what can be expected from the game's final release later this year.

Over on X, Bandai Namco shared what it called its "Numbers from the Night", and it turns out that across the network test as a whole, players slaughtered the Gladius, Beast of Night boss 58,615 times. That's a lot of dead Nightlords.

Spectral Hawks, the ghostly birds used to ferry players across Nightreign's map, were summoned 427,533 times across the network test, while 23.6 million recovery attacks were used to help downed players get back on their feet.

When it comes to Elden Ring Nightreign's minibosses, players killed almost 200,000 Golden Hippopotamuses (Hippopotami?), almost 165,000 Flame Chariots, and just over 150,000 Fire Monks.

Almost 150,000 Flying Dragons of the Hills were killed, and almost 100,000 Royal Knights met their ends at the hands of enterprising warriors. If you think you're going to struggle in Elden Ring Nightreign, let these numbers give you some solace.

On the other hand, almost 38 billion (!) runes were lost by players cumulatively over the course of Nightreign's network test. I like to imagine that 37 billion of those were just one very, very unlucky player.

If you're not familiar with Elden Ring Nightreign, it's an upcoming action RPG spinoff of FromSoftware and Bandai Namco's hugely successful open-world Soulslike Elden Ring, and it represents the developer's first major spinoff for one of its properties.

Nightreign's core gameplay loop sees you and two other players (or just you, but not you and one other) descending onto a map in order to loot it, kill its bosses for XP, and grow strong enough to battle the Nightlord at the end of a three-day period.

The game will feature not only enemies from Elden Ring, but also foes featured in FromSoftware's Dark Souls series, including the likes of the first game's Centipede Demon, Dark Souls 2's The Duke's Dear Freja, and Dark Souls 3's The Nameless King.

Elden Ring Nightreign launches on May 30th on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox. I was lucky enough to get into the network test back in February, and you can read my impressions of it here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Honkai: Star Rail Version 3.2 Release Date Set for April
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/honkai-star-rail-version-32-release-date

HoYoverse has announced the Honkai: Star Rail Version 3.2 release date, with the new update set to bring two new 5-star characters, a perilous new foe to take down, and more in April.

Following on from February's Version 3.1, Honkai: Star Rail Version 3.2, also known as "Through the Petals in the Land of Repose", is set to launch across all platforms on April 9th. HoYoverse is promising "trials of survival and political intrigue" as part of the update's main story.

You'll be traveling to the "forgotten city-state of Styxia" in this update, and while you're there, you'll take on Pollux, a leviathan who slumbers in the River of Souls. Pollux has some pretty nasty HP manipulation attacks, so you'll have to be on your A-game.

Two 5-star characters are coming your way in Honkai: Star Rail Version 3.2. The first, Castorice, is a Remembrance-path character who can sync up with her Netherwing dragon for big damage, although the dragon sacrifices its own HP to use its ultimate attack.

Your second 5-star character in Version 3.2 is Anaxa, an Erudition character who can apply Weaknesses to enemies and boost his damage using his Qualitative Disclosure ability.

The first half of Version 3.2 will also see the return of Fugue, Jiaoqiu, and Acheron as rerun banners, while the second half will give you another chance to obtain the wonderfully-named Dr. Ratio for your team.

Honkai: Star Rail Version 3.2 isn't all about gloomy city-states and frantic combat, though; you can also kick back and enjoy the new Seal Slammers minigame, which allows you to compete against your allies "in chaotic seal-based collisions". Finally.

Honkai: Star Rail is available to play for free right now on PC, PS5, and mobile devices. Version 3.2, also known as "Through the Petals in the Land of Repose", arrives on April 9th.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Live-Action Zelda Movie Gets March 2027 Release Date
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/live-action-zelda-movie-march-2027

Nintendo has announced the release date for the upcoming live-action The Legend of Zelda movie, but don't get too excited; its release is a couple of years away yet.

Per an announcement on the new Nintendo Today! app, which was announced (and released) as part of yesterday's Nintendo Direct show, the Zelda movie will launch around the world on March 26th, 2027.

That date puts the movie's release in the same month as Paramount's Sonic the Hedgehog 4; March is a pretty common month for blockbuster-style movies to be released in, so these two tentpole video game adaptations releasing then makes a lot of sense.

Of course, just because Nintendo has announced a date for the movie, that doesn't mean it won't be delayed or changed later down the line. Still, now you know when you should be clearing your schedule if you're eagerly awaiting the film.

While we don't have a cast or a story outline for the Zelda movie yet, we do know that it'll be co-produced by Nintendo legend Shigeru Miyamoto, alongside Hollywood blockbuster producer Avi Arad, whose name you'll find on movies like Sam Raimi's Spider-Man films.

Additionally, attached to direct the project is The Maze Runner's Wes Ball, who also directed and produced 2024's Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes.

It's likely that we'll hear more about what's coming for the Zelda movie in the months ahead, but Nintendo no doubt won't feel the need to rush; after all, it's got a major console launch to take care of in the next few months.

In case you're unaware, Nintendo is gearing up to release the Switch 2, which will probably be launching sometime in summer. A Nintendo Direct dedicated to the console is due to air next week.

It's likely the company will be looking to focus on that launch before more Zelda movie details are revealed, but it looks like if more info is released soon, it'll probably be via the Nintendo Today! app. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Atelier Yumia Sales Top 300,000, Making It the Series' Fastest-Selling Game
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/atelier-yumia-sales-300k-fastest-selling

Koei Tecmo and Gust have revealed that JRPG Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories & the Envisioned Land has hit a new sales milestone, as well as setting a new record for the series.

Per a post on X (which is in Japanese, so we're using machine translation), Atelier Yumia has sold over 300,000 copies worldwide, which makes it the fastest-selling game in the franchise.

That's not bad given that the game has only been on sale for a week, and since it was released in Japan and around the world simultaneously, that figure doesn't include any long-tail Japanese sales either.

By way of comparison, it took Atelier Ryza 3 around a month to achieve the same figure, and while that game is still the fastest-selling Ryza sub-series game, it can't lay claim to being the series' fastest-selling title.

If you're not familiar with Atelier Yumia, it's the latest game in the long-running Atelier series of JRPGs, which also includes the likes of the aforementioned Atelier Ryza sub-series, as well as free-to-play RPG Atelier Resleriana and its upcoming sequel.

Generally speaking, the games combine typical JRPG exploration and combat with a focus on item synthesis using ingredients gathered in the world, and Atelier Yumia is no different on that front.

Unlike previous games in the series, however, Atelier Yumia is fully open-world; rather than the open-zone environments of prior entries, Yumia allows you to fully and freely explore its map without any loading times to get in your way.

Yumia's success shows that there's still a significant audience out there eager for more Atelier games, so you can expect to see more from this series in the future.

Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories & the Envisioned Land is available right now for PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and Nintendo Switch. You can read our Isaac's review of the game here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
